name: Water Spangles
description: Salvinia minima, commonly known as Water Spangles, Common Salvinia, or Floating Fern, is a free-floating aquatic fern native to Central and South America, particularly Mexico, Central America, and parts of South America, though it has been naturalized in many regions worldwide. It belongs to the Salviniaceae family and features small, round to oval, bright green leaves (1-2 cm across) that float on the water surface. The leaves have a distinctive water-repellent, velvety texture due to tiny hairs that trap air, helping the plant float. The leaves grow in pairs along branching stems, and the plant produces feathery, root-like structures (modified leaves) that hang beneath the water surface. The plant displays a surface-spreading, mat-forming growth habit and forms dense floating mats. In its native habitat, it grows floating on the surface of still or slow-moving freshwater bodies. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant provides excellent surface cover, shade, and natural filtration. It's popular in aquariums for its fast growth and ability to provide cover for fish.
